pullrequest.title: Visualize variables on multiple mesh blocks (exodus_ii)

content.raw: Thanks! I guess I don't know enough about the particle unions to comment on that. It would be an interesting test of our unstructured_mesh code if we ever started supporting unstructured_mesh frontends other than exodus. Certainly what I've done here would apply only to exodus.
content.html: Thanks! I guess I don't know enough about the particle unions to comment on that. It would be an interesting test of our unstructured_mesh code if we ever started supporting unstructured_mesh frontends other than exodus. Certainly what I've done here would apply only to exodus.

pullrequest.title: Visualize variables on multiple mesh blocks (exodus_ii)

content.raw: It might also be a good idea to actually create a new mesh object that is the actual geometric/physical fusion of the two meshes. I think that this would only make sense though if we could test for whether the meshes are conforming.
content.html: It might also be a good idea to actually create a new mesh object that is the actual geometric/physical fusion of the two meshes. I think that this would only make sense though if we could test for whether the meshes are conforming.

pullrequest.title: Visualize variables on multiple mesh blocks (exodus_ii)

content.raw:
Here's the documentation on particle unions: http://yt-project.org/docs/dev/analyzing/filtering.html#particle-unions

The 'all' particle type is just a particle union. You can see how that's implemented here: https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/src/98bb0abc0b1421cba1c16df4ecca2ebd861d36d6/yt/data_objects/static_output.py?at=yt&fileviewer=file-view-default#static_output.py-518
content.html:
Here's the documentation on particle unions: http://yt-project.org/docs/dev/analyzing/filtering.html#particle-unions

The 'all' particle type is just a particle union. You can see how that's implemented here: https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/src/98bb0abc0b1421cba1c16df4ecca2ebd861d36d6/yt/data_objects/static_output.py?at=yt&fileviewer=file-view-default#static_output.py-518

pullrequest.title: Visualize variables on multiple mesh blocks (exodus_ii)

content.raw: Ok, looking through, I think there's definitely a good analogy between potential mesh unions and particle unions. The ParticleUnion class itself has no behavior intrinsic to particles such that it couldn't identically be used for mesh unions. In the most recent commit I've added a toy `mesh_union` member to the `ExodusIIUnstructuredIndex` class. It is used very trivially now in `IOHandlerExodusII._read_fuid_selection`. I could use it better if I knew non-clumsy ways to initialize multi-dimensional arrays of arbitrary `n` dimension
content.html: Ok, looking through, I think there's definitely a good analogy between potential mesh unions and particle unions. The ParticleUnion class itself has no behavior intrinsic to particles such that it couldn't identically be used for mesh unions. In the most recent commit I've added a toy mesh_union member to the ExodusIIUnstructuredIndex class. It is used very trivially now in IOHandlerExodusII._read_fuid_selection. I could use it better if I knew non-clumsy ways to initialize multi-dimensional arrays of arbitrary n dimension

pullrequest.title: Visualize variables on multiple mesh blocks (exodus_ii)

content.raw: I know there are ways to do it; but I've never found I've really liked. Anyone have a favorite way to initialize a multi-dimensional array such that line 54 could get merged into the `for` loop?
content.html: I know there are ways to do it; but I've never found I've really liked. Anyone have a favorite way to initialize a multi-dimensional array such that line 54 could get merged into the for loop?

pullrequest.title: Visualize variables on multiple mesh blocks (exodus_ii)

content.raw:
You could use a list comprehension:

`ci = np.concatenate([self.handler.variables['connect%d' % i] for i in range(len(self.index.meshes)))])`
content.html:
You could use a list comprehension:

ci = np.concatenate([self.handler.variables['connect%d' % i] for i in range(len(self.index.meshes)))])

content.html: Maybe we should replace ParticleUnion with this? It looks like they're the same.

pullrequest.title: Visualize variables on multiple mesh blocks (exodus_ii)

content.raw: Love it. Thanks!
content.html: Love it. Thanks!

pullrequest.title: Visualize variables on multiple mesh blocks (exodus_ii)

content.raw: From an output standpoint, I think this is ready for review. I will do 3D but I need to cook up a test 3D data-set first. I think that could be a separate PR if others agree. When iterating over meshes, I could just as easily replace `index.mesh_union` with `index.meshes` and then there wouldn't be a need to create a new index member attribute. This would in turn eliminate the need for the new `Union` class (I could have used `ParticleUnion`...but the name doesn't work :-)) But maybe introducing a mesh union concept in analogy with particle union is worth it, in which case I would vote for aliasing `ParticleUnion` and `MeshUnion` to `Union`. I don't really care myself.
content.html: From an output standpoint, I think this is ready for review. I will do 3D but I need to cook up a test 3D data-set first. I think that could be a separate PR if others agree. When iterating over meshes, I could just as easily replace index.mesh_union with index.meshes and then there wouldn't be a need to create a new index member attribute. This would in turn eliminate the need for the new Union class (I could have used ParticleUnion...but the name doesn't work :-)) But maybe introducing a mesh union concept in analogy with particle union is worth it, in which case I would vote for aliasing ParticleUnion and MeshUnion to Union. I don't really care myself.

pullrequest.title: Visualize variables on multiple mesh blocks (exodus_ii)

content.raw: To avoid the code duplication, why not make `ParticleUnion` and `MeshUnion` trivial subclasses of `Union`?
content.html: To avoid the code duplication, why not make ParticleUnion and MeshUnion trivial subclasses of Union?

pullrequest.title: Visualize variables on multiple mesh blocks (exodus_ii)

content.raw: That works too and also makes good object oriented sense. You like that better than aliasing?
content.html: That works too and also makes good object oriented sense. You like that better than aliasing?

pullrequest.title: Visualize variables on multiple mesh blocks (exodus_ii)

content.raw: As a policy, new features should include documentation as part of the pull request that adds a new feature. This ensures we don't get into a state where we have lots of undocumented new features, mandating a doc sprint before we can do a release. It also ensures the documentation is high quality, since it will still be fresh in the code author's head.
content.html: As a policy, new features should include documentation as part of the pull request that adds a new feature. This ensures we don't get into a state where we have lots of undocumented new features, mandating a doc sprint before we can do a release. It also ensures the documentation is high quality, since it will still be fresh in the code author's head.

I'd suggest adding one more entry to http://yt-project.org/doc/visualizing/plots.html#unstructured-mesh-slices that shows off this behavior.
content.html:
I just tested this out, and it looks great to me. Everything worked as expected on the datasets I have. I also made a quick pass over the code and don't see any issues.

I'd suggest adding one more entry to http://yt-project.org/doc/visualizing/plots.html#unstructured-mesh-slices that shows off this behavior.

pullrequest.title: Visualize variables on multiple mesh blocks (exodus_ii)

content.raw: It clashes with @jzuhone 's PR 2465, hence the latest errors you are seeing. A bit of history: `local_varia` was introduced when I managed tests' parallelisation by hand. Right now, creating a new "bucket" doesn't introduce any additional upkeep cost. I would recommend splitting this into separate, logically relevant pieces like `local_unstructured`, `local_photons` etc. Be more creative with the names than me :)
content.html: It clashes with John ZuHone 's PR 2465, hence the latest errors you are seeing. A bit of history: local_varia was introduced when I managed tests' parallelisation by hand. Right now, creating a new "bucket" doesn't introduce any additional upkeep cost. I would recommend splitting this into separate, logically relevant pieces like local_unstructured, local_photons etc. Be more creative with the names than me :)
